title: Day 2
text:
Onboarding
I got settled at my desk and spent the day absorbing HydoTech pamphlets—learning about the company’s massive footprint in China and globally—and reading a detailed BCG report on the Hydrogen Energy Industry to get the “big picture” view. I learned about the different project completed or under completion at Hydotech and within China, related to Hydrogen energy. Notably, and perhaps more salient to an international crowd, the Beijing Olympics featured a fleet of hydrogen fuel cell buses. The torch in the Beijing Olympics was a hydrogen powered torch too.

title: Day 4
text:
Research Hurdle
Back at the office, the challenge ramped up. I was tasked with researching the stability of Nickel phases in an alkaline medium. This was a double-edged sword:

The Science: I’m new to electrochemistry, so the concepts were fresh.
The Toolset: I had to navigate the Chinese internet and Chinese AI tools.

I’m used to American web infrastructure, so suddenly not having my usual digital “crutches” made the learning curve steep. I spent the afternoon combing through references, line by line, paper by paper. One of my biggest curiosities was how the Chinese AI tools would perform when prompted in English and required to output an English answer. I am interested in looking this up later. I am not sure what the training process or training data is, and if it exludes English, how that affects performance. I wouldn’t be surprised, though, if there was some mechanism found around this. This is all to say, though, that I used almost no AI for my project because:
1- The prompting took very long. I had to keep reminding it to respond in English.
2- I was not confident in the accuracy of the responses, given the language barrier and the fact that I was asking it to respond in a language that it may not have been trained on.

title: Day 6
text:
Today, Vanessa, Mr. Gu, and I drove out to the suburbs of Jiangsu to visit the motor controller manufacturing center that are supplying HydoTech with the CVM controllers. Specifically, the device we were going to look at was the one that takes the CVM data that I had been analyzing over the past few days. This same device is those detailed in the electrical schematics that I had looked at. The latter part of this day was a heavy-hitting technical day.
The drive through the countryside was beautiful, and gave me a good idea of what Jiangsu countryside actually looks like. I thought the factory was in the countryside, but I was completely wrong. The factory is still considered to be in Nanjing- this just shows you how massive the city is! Even the town in the countryside that we visited was very big and had lots of apartment buildings that were at least over 15 stories. In the US, I would call this a little city, but here it is considered a village. Before arriving at the manufacturing center, we had a delicious lunch from the region.

title: Day 6
text:
Stop 1: The R&D Field Station
We saw a testbench for a big electrolyzer that the clients wanted Mr. Gu to take a look at. Their testbench was further away, and simply in the middle of some field. I was curious why this was the case, potentially that they didn’t want others taking their IP, but didn’t ask. Both Mr. Gu and the Gentleman from the manufacturing center studied in Aachen, and the two of them had the same advisor at Tsinghua University. I spoke a bit of German with this Gentleman.
The testbench is quite a machine, consuming CO2 and recycling its own heat. Seeing technology with that kind of prospect for the future was inspiring.
The region we drove through going back to the center was entirely industrial. This was, again, another interesting insight for me into China.

title: Day 6
text:
Stop 2: Manufacturing
We toured the assembly lines (a mix of full and partial automation) where they seal the controller PCBs. I was really surprised by all the different projects undertaken by the company. First the electrolyser testbench, which is mostly electrochemistry theory, and has hardly anything to do with embedded controllers. They also do all of their own PCB assembly which, for the amount of PCBs they assemble potentially makes sense, but is a whole new set of infrastructure and work that has to be accounted for. Then, all of the sealing of the controller PCBs and actual assembly. The Gentleman also informed me that they do all the software for the chips- which I can only imagine is a entire new undertaking, something a whole different company could rationally be hired to do.
We were also taken to another building where walked through the vibration and environmental testing rooms—rigorous stuff. As manufacturers of such products, you have liability for what you ship to be working. All of this testing needs to be accounted for as well.

title: Day 6
text:
The CVM Test
Finally, we got our hands on the HydoTech CVM controller system I had studied the day before. Here is how the system flow worked:

Distribution: Test voltage leads to probes connecting to the electrolyzer substrate.
Conversion: Inside the controller, voltage is converted to a two-byte representation and biased upward (to avoid negatives).
Transmission: Transmission: Data is sent via two CAN ports \(\rightarrow\) CAN-to-Ethernet gateway \(\rightarrow\) Modbus conversion \(\rightarrow\) Gateway.
Cloud: Over the router, data goes via 5G to the server.

We validated the real-time data on the computer using a multimeter.



Probing the CVM Controller with a Multimeter

title: Day 7
text:
Further Research
I continued my research into the phases of Nickel at 30 wt% KOH. I found different papers that took different approaches of experimentation to characterize the phases. Some were contradictory, leading me to look deeper into the conditions under which the experiments took place. I first looked into the different types of experimentation, to better understand what data was exactly being extracted- what exactly was being measured and by what means. These included Raman Spectroscopies, Cyclic Voltammetries, Pourbaix Diagrams, and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopies. Once I had a better idea, I began writing down the different experimental conditions.
Later, I started realizing that I would need to progress in some other ways. I knew that I would be busy in the upcoming days with travel and sightseeing plans, and I wouldnt be able to understand everything about the mechanisms surrounding the evolution of Nickel species in the few days of work that I had remaining.
As I have previously mentioned, I wasn’t able to employ AI as well in this instance to arrive at a better understanding and be able to move forward in my research. I decided that the best way for me to make substantial progress and produce a meaningful deliverable for Mr. Gu was if I learned from professionals in the field. I started gathering a list of professors and researchers in the field of Nickel-based catalysts, and I reached out to them to ask for references that I might find useful in my research. Just writing the emails and collecting the list took me the whole rest of the day, but I was happy to have gotten started on this, and allowing them a bit of time to respond given the holidays.

title: Day 10
text:
Dinner
For dinner, I met Dr. Yao, Dr. Hu, Dr. Su, Junming, and a future colleague of HydoTech called Sam. Sam graduated from Yale, and also spend some time in Cornell, so we had some common things to talk about from the US University system. I spoke with Dr. Su about his work and learned a lot about cooperation and developments in Europe. I was surprised by many different things that I learned, both from how different the US and Chinese developments in Hydrogen Energy are, to how much he recommended the French University system, to how slow he attributed processes in Europe due to beauraucracy. He also told me a lot about Ordos, which was interesting for me to learn before we departed the next morning. I had no idea that Ordos was such a wealthy city. Coming from the US, it was a city- and even province or area that I had never heard of before.
The dinner was Italian food, and I found this interesting because we were in the “International Neighborhood” of Beijing- where all the embassys are.
It was very nice to sit with everyone and observe company dynamics from a different perspective. Being in the Nanjing office up until now, I had only been around the people who work in that office, who are essentially everyone working under the people at the table now. So being at the table with everyone- especially Dr. Yao- was great to see the “orchestrators” of the company I had gotten to know up to this time. This is especially because, from my conversations with different employees in the Nanjing office, everyone seems genuinely so content with the leadership, company culture, and employment base. Moreover, understanding the deep ties that everyone at the table has to the university and understanding how their research and work overlapped before HydoTech was founded, was a great insight into the company and its roots.

title: Day 1
text:
One Mall
It was my first time experiencing the mall culture in China. There are many big malls in cities, each with many stores. It is typical for people to go over the weekend. These malls are all much bigger than those in the US, and it seems to be much more of a culture to go to the mall, even just to walk around. The One Mall was a very nice mall, with many high-end stores. My first taste of local flavors were:

An Americano with Orange Juice from LuckyCoffee
Lunch of traditional local food. Most notably, some authentic Nanjing Duck.




Lunch Restaurant

Dinner
After a much-needed power nap at the hotel, we met Mr. Gu for dinner. We tried cuisine from the Hong Kong region. It was definitely different in flavor to the Jiangsu meal I had for lunch, showing how different all the flavors across China can be. It was a perfect, savory end to a long travel day.

Dinner
For dinner, Mr. Gu, Vanessa and I went to an amazing barbeque place that Mr. Gu had previously visited with his friends. The restaurant was very small, and had a very local feel to it. The food was amazing. We ordered a bunch of different types of meat, and they were all so flavorful. This might have been my favorite meal during my time in China, just because the food was sooo good. It was a great way to end the day after being out in the cold for long.



Barbeque in Beijing


It was also really great to be spending time with Vanessa and Mr. Gu. It gave me insight into my future work- I definitely aspire to have colleagues where I can have fun with them outside of work, and have a good relationship with them. I know that both of them work really hard and are very dedicated to their work, but it was nice to see that they also have fun together and can enjoy each other’s company outside of work. I think that is really important for a good work environment and culture.

For dinner, Sia, Yutong, and two of Sia’s friends and I went to Haidilao for Hotpot. I got my nails done, which comes as a package of getting the food. I tried many new different foods, including: Duck brain, duck blood, chicken feet, and cow intestine. I really liked the cow intestine. Yutong came late to dinner, although we were eating around eight, because she had more work that she wanted to get done. I had been sitting opposite her the whole day, observing how focused she was since the morning. This went to show how hardworking the startup scene is here.

title: Day 8
text:
Over the weekend, I took the train by myself to Shanghai. I was expecting to have a much more difficult journey, considering that I do not speak the language and do not have a passport from here. I arrived at the train station with only 20 minutes before my departure, so I was a bit stressed about not making it. Instead, I had about ten minutes sitting on the train before we took off, because everything went so quickly. The process went extremely smoothly. The train took just over one hour. The distance travelled is the same as New York to Boston. But the New York to Boston train takes around four hours.



Nanjingnan Station


In Shanghai, I also took the metro, which was extremely easy to navigate and use. Simply a QR code. Just like the train from Nanjingan.
I walked around Jing’an, as per a recommendation from my friend. It was warmer than in Nanjing, which made it more pleasant to walk around. I went by a bunch of cool shops and nice houses.
I also saw the Jing’an Temple, which was a massive temple made of mostly wood and gold, right in the middle of the city, surrounded by malls on every corner. I found this so interesting. It really showed the character of Shanghai as a city: history, but also extremely modern.



Jing’an Temple


I continued to just walk around the area that I was in, because it was so nice. I had a matcha and then started walking to ward the train station so that I could make my train home. Once in Nanjing, I took the subway home and got to bed.

title: Day 11
text:
We took an early flight to Ordos. From above, it was cool to see the landscape transform from flat land to mountainous. Entering Ordos, the airport was relatively empty, and the town didn’t seem too full. But let me introduce you to it:

Ordos has the biggest GDP of any city in China
Ordos is the 3rd largest city in China by area, but only has a population of around 1 million people
Ordos has one third of China’s coal
Ordos is situated at the feet of the mountains, and is surrounded by dessert, making it favorable for both wind and solar energy

title: Day 11
text:
Solar Panels



Solar Panel Field


We visited the largest pattterened solar field in the whole world in the Kubuqi desert. The field is set out to have the pattern of a horse. We were able to go up several observation towers, but even going up to the top of the talles one, it was not possible to discern any part of the horse.



Solar Panel Field NASA Observatory Image


It was very impressive to imagine the amount of power being produced, standing up there and not being able to see the end of all the infrastructure. There seemed to be multiple projects all around the area. The gentleman who took us up the observation tower told us that his company also had a 40 GW project nearby. That is equivalent to the entire US grid storage capacity. But this is contained in just a single solar PV project in China. From an American perspective, it was quite a shocking realization.
We then also decided to inspect the PV panels up close. There was snow on the ground, but during the summer, the land under the solar panels is used for agricultural purposes becuase the solar panels provide shade for the crops. Otherwise, the intensity of the sun would be too strong. At the backs of the panels, we looked at the electrical connections and determined that the ones we were looking at were not turned on at the time.

title: Day 11
text:
Desert
Later in the desert, we took a quick stop at a Quad bike rental place. It was my first time ever doing something like that.
Both Vanessa and Mr. Gu got stuck in the sand at one point. In trying to get out, they accelerated their back wheels and made sand fly over them. Because they were both facing forward at the time, neither of them realized, and the sand was flying over their heads. It was very funny to watch.



Mr. Gu and I Look Funny on the Bike


We then went on driving back through the desert landscape. It was beautiful. Other than the piles of sand, there was also bright red rock and some greenery. Once we arrived in an area closer to windmills, we decided to try to drive to their base and inspect them up close. We got to the base of one of the windmills, and it was really interesting to see how they were built. The shape- especially of the blades- was unqiue and intentionally designed. It was very loud standing right next to the moving blades, simply because of the amount of wind each wind was pushing past. This view once again gave an impression of how large-scale the energy industry is in China.



Windmill


By the end of the day, I had seen the following energy infrastructure:

Solar panels
Windmills
The HydoTech testbench
Coal mines from the airplane
A dam from the airplane

I am so grateful to have had the opportunity to see all of this in person, and to have a better understanding of the scale of the industry in China.

title: Day 9
text:
Lunch and University
From there, we went to have lunch by Tsinghua University. We had traditional noodels with lots of colourful veggies put in.



Noodles in Beijing


We stopped at the Tsinghua University gate to take pictures and go to the gift store. In front of us taking pictures were two boys. They had just started their first year of high school, but were already taking pictures in front of the University gate, in hopes of getting in there in the future. This just shows how competitive the school is. Mr. Gu said that around 50 people per province get in, so it is a bit different than US acceptance rates, as it depends who got above a certain curved point on the examinations. We then went into the gift store and I bought a big jacket for Inner Mongolia. My first twenty minutes outside in Beijing showed me that I might need it.



Person Taking Pictures in Wishful Thinking in Front of Tsinghua Gate

title: Day 9
text:
Forbidden City
Next, we went to the Forbidden City. It was unbelievably big. It took Vanessa and I thirty minutes to walk straight across, even though we hardly stopped. And this didn’t account for all the other edges and different corners there were to visit. I believe we likely only saw about 10%. I was in complete awe of the whole place. I was also completely freezing. I would have loved to see it in summer, so that I could have had more time to appreciate all the different corners. I was just so freezing cold there, despite my two big jackets, that I could hardly think straight.



Forbidden City


Mr. Gu didn’t book a ticket in time, so he wasn’t let in. We met up with him afterwards and warmed up in a mall. We had Chagee Milk Tea and then walked around a bit. We decided it would be a good idea to buy gloves for the next day. Then, we went and visited popmar and played some games in the games room. At Popmart there were SO many people. I was so surprised by how many people were obsessed with these little dolls that you couldn’t even choose to buy on your own. I suppose I understand how appealing the game of being involved in the collecting process is. Each of us got a doll, I chose the little prince doll. None of us got the doll we wanted.



Popmart Dolls


Next, we went to play games in the pick-up hall. We bought 210 coins and only collected 7 dolls. We averaged ten tries per doll. I think we all realized we were pretty bad. It was a cool insight into things that Chinese people my age do, as we don’t have this type of game in the US.



Vanessa Trying to Pick a Doll

title: Day 11
text:
We took an early flight to Ordos. From above, it was cool to see the landscape transform from flat land to mountainous. Entering Ordos, the airport was relatively empty, and the town didn’t seem too full. But let me introduce you to it:

Ordos has the biggest GDP of any city in China
Ordos is the 3rd largest city in China by area, but only has a population of around 1 million people
Ordos has one third of China’s coal
Ordos is situated at the feet of the mountains, and is surrounded by dessert, making it favorable for both wind and solar energy

title: Day 10
text:
The Great Wall
Our next stop was the Great Wall. We took the train to the Badaling section of the wall, which is the most popular section. It was very crowded, but it was still an amazing experience to see the wall in person. I had seen it in pictures and videos before, but it was still breathtaking to see it in person. The view from the top of the wall was incredible, and I could see for miles in every direction. It was a bit difficult to climb up, especially with the cold weather and my boots, but it was definitely worth it. I was surprised by how crowded it was, given it was a week day, but I think it just shows how popular and important the Great Wall is to people in China.



The Great Wall


Many people were reciting a poem about the Great Wall about the dragon, which I had never heard before. It was interesting to see how much the wall is celebrated and ingrained in the culture and history of China.

title: Day 13

Morning
I then headed to the office and went over my slides once more. I gave my presentation to the team, and I was happy with how it went. I had a good discussion with the team about my findings and they provided me with some helpful feedback on how to improve my work going forward. For one, I learned that the simple pH calculation that I used to calculate the pH of 30% wt KOH = 14.85 was false. This calculation is only valid for pHs below 14. It was a good opportunity to share my work and get feedback from professionals in the field.

title: Day 14
text:
Bipolar Metal Plates
We first went to a company that manufactures metal bipolar plates for hydrogen fuel cell applications. They use a pressing technology that is used in other applications- for example in the making of car doors- to press the pattern for the bipolar plates into the metal sheets. The precision that these technologies have is very impressive: 0.05 cm plate thickness and 0.03 cm engraving depth.
We saw a Hydrogen drone, which was very cool. It has a much longer lifetime than a lithium ion battery, and was said to manage operationality of up to three hours. It is mostly used for military and agricultural purposes because it can lift heavy loads.



Hydrogen Drone


I then joined a meeting between Mr. Gu and the representative at this supplier. They kept the working language in Chinese, so I wasn’t able to understand much, but it was insightful to see how different players in this industry interact and form relationships with each other.

title: Day 14
text:
Break and Beach
Mr. Gu was then joining a meeting that I wasn’t allowed to sit in on. I had about two hours of time, so I decided to take a Didi car to the beach since we were nearby. It was a sunny day and I was able to take a nice walk along the water.



Shangai Beach


At this point, I have now visited:

A Chinese Desert
A Chinese Beach
The Chinese Mountains
Many Chinese Cities
The Chinese Countryside

I felt like this was somewhat full circle, and it was a reminder of how grateful I am to have been exposed to so much during my truly short stay here.

title: Day 14
text:
H-Rise
I returned and met Mr. Gu. We took off for the next manufacturers: H-Rise. They focus on the develpment and manufacturing of fuel cell stacks. Because they have received traction from Investors and Government officials, they had a downstairs area that was dedicated to showcasing the technologies they have produced. As an outside perspective, this was an insightful way to digest the work done by the company and the different projects that they have in place.
We were taken through a few of their different test facilties. We saw a single 1.5 MW electrolyser, which was again so impressive for me to understand the scale of.
Some of their tiny plates were subjected to 2.5 A per cm^2 flowing through them.
Once again, Mr. Gu and the gentleman we were visiting presented a slide deck to each other of their respective companies and work. This was another point of insight into industry interactions. Mr. Gu brought up the issue of electrode corrosion and asked the gentleman if he had ever seen or experienced something similar. This was a point that was so interesting to me- even though the both of them work at different companies within the same industry and would otherwise be seen as competitors, they were eager to support each other and move forward as a single effort. The gentleman thought hard and tried to provide genuine help for Mr. Gu’s corrosion issues.
It turned dark out as we left H-Rise. The car ride back to Shanghai was quite long, but it was nice to recap and digest everything I had seen with Mr. Gu.

title: Day 14
text:
Morning and Trip back Home
The next morning, I woke up early to make the train back to Nanjing. I got some street food breakfast and hopped right onto the train. Once in Nanjing, I packed my bags, grabbed a quick lunch, and headed to the airport. My connection flight was first to Seoul, and then I would be going from there to LA.
School starts in two days, but I have had the most amazing experience here over the past two weeks. I am not sure how I will adjust back to being on my small campus, in my small university bubble after this experience.
